H0.text: The gravity of Earth produces the Coriolis Effect, which causes air traveling away from the equator to be deflected to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere.

H1.text: The rotation of Earth produces the Coriolis Effect, which causes air traveling away from the equator to deflect to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere.

H2.text: The axial tilt of Earth produces the Coriolis effect, which causes air moving away from the equator to be deflected to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere, preventing the air from following a straight path.

H3.text: The revolution of Earth is the factor that produces the Coriolis Effect, which causes air moving away from the equator to be deflected to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere.

A4.text: Because the Earth rotates, Earth-bound observers need to account for the Coriolis force to correctly analyze the motion of objects.

A5.text: The Coriolis force is a pseudo force that acts on objects in motion within a frame of reference that rotates with respect to an inertial frame.
